s.text: A MEDLINE search was conducted using databases from 1966 to May 1997.
Accordingly, on the basis of existing evidence, the use of dopamine to improve renal function cannot be recommended.
Virtually all studies have used hydration (usually with 0.45% saline) in addition to the agent being tested and most authors recommend its use.
Given these considerations, and in the absence of clinical data, diuretics cannot be recommended to prevent ATN.

Indeed, dopamine's multiple effects (even at low doses) make it the perfect pressor/inotropic agent when such a combination is warranted.
The most a clinician can do is to manage the complications of ARF and limit further renal insult so as to assure the best chance of renal recovery.

The results of a small level V study by Palmieri et al [ 26] appear to suggest that dopamine may be useful in shortening the recovery time from interleukin-2-induced ARF.
Although the pathogenesis of renal injury secondary to radiocontrast agents is not entirely understood, it appears to be due to medullary ischemia [ 3, 50].
1. For prophylaxsis against radiocontrast-induced ATN, saline infusion should be administered for optimal hydration; neither diuretics nor dopamine appear effective and may be harmful.
In this regard, loop diuretics appear to be more effective and less toxic when given as a continuous infusion rather than as a bolus.
Given these considerations, and in the absence of clinical data, diuretics cannot be recommended to prevent ATN.
